title: Vulnerability & Trust
description: Explore how vulnerability and trust shape your intimate connection.

questions.text: Feeling vulnerable during intimacy is something I...
choices: Am learning to be more comfortable with

therapeutic.rationale: Vulnerability comfort in intimacy reveals attachment patterns. Welcomers find intimacy freeing; strugglers want closeness but fear exposure; learners are growing; protectors have walls. These patterns often trace to early experiences.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The welcomer may not understand the protector's walls; the protector may envy the welcomer's ease. Different comfort levels need patience and safety.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared vulnerability comfort creates mutual understanding. You know what intimacy requires emotionally for each other.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How comfortable are you being vulnerable during intimacy? What makes it easier or harder?

questions.text: What helps me feel safe being intimate is...
choices: Knowing I'm truly accepted as I am
Knowing my partner respects my limits

therapeutic.rationale: Safety sources vary. Acceptance-needers want unconditional regard; trust-builders need track record; connection-needers want emotional closeness; limit-respecters need boundary honor. Knowing your partner's safety source helps you provide it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different safety needs mean providing different things. The acceptance-needer may need more verbal affirmation; the limit-respecter may need more check-ins.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared safety source makes creating intimacy easier. You naturally provide what your partner needs.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes you feel truly safe being intimate? What would destroy that safety?

questions.text: When I feel insecure about something intimate, I tend to...

therapeutic.rationale: Insecurity handling affects intimacy quality. Sharers process with their partner; keepers suffer silently; internal-workers process alone; indirect-seekers hope for mind-reading. Partners can't address what they don't know about.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The sharer may overwhelm the keeper; the keeper may leave the sharer feeling shut out. Find a way to let your partner in on your insecurities.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared insecurity response means you process similarly. You understand each other's internal experience.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: When you feel insecure about something intimate, what do you do with that feeling? Does your partner know?

questions.text: The trust I need to feel fully open intimately comes from...
choices: How my partner treats me outside the bedroom
Knowing my partner keeps intimate things private

therapeutic.rationale: Trust foundations for intimacy vary. Daily-treatment watchers see patterns; moment-focusers need consistent respect; privacy-needers require discretion; holistic types need all three. Understanding your trust foundation helps your partner build it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different trust foundations mean emphasizing different behaviors. All are important—understand which matters most to your partner.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared trust foundation makes building safety straightforward. You're both looking for the same things.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What builds your trust for intimacy? What would break it?

questions.text: I want my partner to know that in intimate moments, I need...
choices: To feel like the focus isn't on performance

therapeutic.rationale: Intimate needs reveal vulnerabilities. Pace-needers feel rushed; reassurance-needers need words; attunement-needers need physical presence; non-performance-needers fear judgment. Naming these needs helps your partner provide them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different needs require different giving. Learn what your partner most needs and prioritize providing it.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared needs mean you understand each other's intimate vulnerabilities intuitively.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you most need from your partner during intimate moments? Have you told them?
